# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia code:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(d::Date)
    throw(ArgumentError("Can't increase time of a Date type."))
end
```

In this code, the `timezone_bumper` function takes one argument: the date-time object (`DateTime`) or the date object (`Date`).

If it receives a DateTime, it simply adds the number of hours specified in the bump parameter to the datetime and returns the new datetime. By default, bump is set to 3. If bump is not provided, it defaults to 3.

If timezone_bumper receives a Date type, it throws an error saying that you can't increase time for a Date type.

This function ensures that only DateTime types are accepted and increases the time as per your request. It also handles exceptions gracefully in case of Date type input, throwing an ArgumentError if such an attempt is made.
